content: Suppose we have a substance with a mass of 100 g and we want to determine the amount of energy required to raise its temperature from 273 K to 293 K. How can we express this using a formula?

To determine the amount of energy required to raise the temperature of a substance, you can use the formula for specific heat capacity:

\[ Q = mc\Delta T \]

Where:
- \( Q \) is the heat energy absorbed or released (in joules),
- \( m \) is the mass of the substance (in grams),
- \( c \) is the specific heat capacity of the substance (in joules per gram per kelvin, J/g·K),
- \(\Delta T\) is the change in temperature (in kelvin, K).

In your case:
- \( m = 100 \, \text{g} \),
- \(\Delta T = 293 \, \text{K} - 273 \, \text{K} = 20 \, \text{K} \).

The specific heat capacity (\( c \)) will depend on the substance in question. Once you know the specific heat capacity, you can plug in the values into the formula to find \( Q \).

For example, if the specific heat capacity of the substance is \( c = 4.18 \, \text{J/g·K} \) (which is the specific heat capacity for water), the calculation would be:

\[ Q = 100 \, \text{g} \times 4.18 \, \text{J/g·K} \times 20 \, \text{K} \]

\[ Q = 8360 \, \text{J} \]

So, 8360 joules of energy would be required to raise the temperature of 100 g of this substance from 273 K to 293 K. You will need the specific heat capacity of the actual substance to perform the calculation accurately.
